**How you did**

You chose **B – the horizontal line through the cross‑bar**.  
That answer is **not correct** for the capital letter **A**.

*Why?*  
A line of symmetry must divide the figure into two parts that are exact mirror images.  
If you fold the letter **A** along a **horizontal** line through the middle of the cross‑bar, the top half (the two sloping sides) does **not** line up with the bottom half (the cross‑bar and the vertical stem). The two halves look different, so the figure is **not** symmetric about that line.

The correct line of symmetry for this **A** is the **vertical line** that runs straight down the middle, splitting the left and right sides. When you fold along that line, the left sloping side matches the right sloping side perfectly.

## 🌟 Next practice – “Spot the symmetry lines”

Since you’ve identified the correct vertical line, let’s strengthen that skill by looking at a shape that **has more than one symmetry line**. This will help you see why some lines work and others don’t.

### The shape
A **regular kite** (two pairs of equal‑length sides; the kite is symmetric left‑right but not top‑bottom).

```
      /\       
     /  \      
    /____\     
   /      \    
  /        \   
```

*(Imagine the figure is drawn so the left and right halves are mirror images, while the top and bottom are different.)*

### Statements  
Select **all** that are true (write the numbers you think work, e.g., “1, 4”).

1️⃣ A **vertical line** that runs through the exact centre, from the top vertex straight down to the bottom vertex.  
2️⃣ A **horizontal line** that runs through the exact centre, from the left‑most point to the right‑most point.  
3️⃣ A **diagonal line** from the top vertex to the left‑bottom corner.  
4️⃣ A **diagonal line** from the top vertex to the right‑bottom corner.  
5️⃣ An **off‑centre vertical line**, e.g., a line one‑third of the way from the left side.

### How to think about it
- **Symmetry line = perfect folding.** Imagine folding the kite along each suggested line. Does one half land exactly on the other?
- The kite’s left and right sides are mirror images, so the **vertical centre line** (statement 1) should work.
- The top and bottom are not mirror images, so a **horizontal line** (statement 2) will not line up.
- The two diagonal lines (statements 3 & 4) each cut the kite into pieces of different shape, so they are **not** symmetry lines.
- An **off‑centre line** (statement 5) always creates mismatched pieces, so it is also **not** a symmetry line.
